intro: Abies chensiensis subsp. yulongxueshanensis, commonly known as the Yulong Snow Mountain fir, is a rare and endemic conifer found in the high-altitude regions of Yulong Snow Mountain in Yunnan Province, China. It is characterized by its slender, pyramidal tree form and dark green, needle-like leaves that are arranged in spirals along the branches. The cones are typically small and cylindrical, maturing to a reddish-brown color, and the tree produces a distinctive, aromatic resin. This subspecies thrives in cool, moist climates with well-drained soil, often growing in mixed forests at elevations above 3,000 meters. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species facing threats from climate change and habitat loss.

It grows in cool, moist, and relatively sheltered habitats within the mountainous terrain. The plant is adapted to the harsh climate and limited soil conditions of its native environment. Its distribution is restricted to this specific mountain range, making it a rare and endemic species.
